subject: Re: [junit] How to test private methods in a class.

messageBody:
Maarten wrote:

>Question: in how far should your production code be
>adapted to accomodate testing with JUnit?
>
>
As far as necessary.

>Should it be possible to use JUnit with All/Any form
>of Production Code?
>
No.

Okay, they weren't very helpful answers. Let's try something a bit better...

For any given problem, a number of designs can be found. A certain
percentage of these will be easy to test. Another percentage will be
hard to test. If you want to be able to use tests to verify your design,
it is reasonable to alter your design to fall in the "easy-to-test" zone.

Designs built with testing in mind from day one will, almost by
definition, be easy to test. This is not a surprising characteristic -
after all, they've been shaped with "ease-of-testing" as a constraint.
Designs built without testing in mind will probably be hard to test,
maybe even "de-testable".

Whenver you make a design, you are balancing various constraints,
forcees, and fears. The "private method" one is a classic: you don't
want to make the method public, because it may be abused. You don't want
to extract a new class for the method to live on because it means
yet-another-class to clutter up your application. You don't want to make
it private, because it's hard to test.

Balancing these forces is what leads to a good design, normally. Taking
easy ways out (such as using reflection to access private methods) tends
to result in imbalanced forces and designs that aren't as good, _in my
experience_.

In this particular situation, my normal technique is to extract to a
package-level class. What I tend to end up with is a few public classes
(about what you'd normally expect), with a lot more package-level
classes that JavaDoc doesn't show off. It seems to work for me. It also
means I usually have lots of smallish classes, which seems to be a
common trait to good OO projects.

Robert.
